intro: Pimpinella rosthornii, commonly known as the African bishop's weed, is a flowering plant native to southern Africa. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small white or yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is often found in open grasslands. It has a taproot system and produces small, dry fruits that contain several seeds. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal potential, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens.
